Dear Ms. Hardin:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on February
24, 2020 thru February 27/2020 and March 4, 2020. Due to the violations of applicable
licensing rules, sections of the contract and ISEP requirements, a written corrective action
plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations
of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 An explanation why previous corrective action plans have not
obtained and maintained compliance for rules found in repeat
noncompliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
In one of five employee records reviewed where a written
annual evaluation was due, the evaluation was 14 days late.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2019, Interim 2018.
R 400.12306 Application request.
(3) An agency shall document that a person who has met the
requirements of subrule (1) of this rule has received an
application and information regarding all of the following:
(a) A copy of the act.
(b) Administrative rules for foster homes.
(c) Administrative rules for child placing agencies.
(d) Good moral character rules.
(e) The child protection law.
(f) The children's ombudsman act.
Two of four enrolled home records reviewed did not show
documentation of (a)-(f).
R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, and
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons interviewed,
and names of interviewers. If children are interviewed, their last
names shall not be included in the report.
4

Three of eight special evaluations reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of the place of contact for each
person interviewed by the interviewer.
R400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent, then the reason why
return is not possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R400.1204(4).
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer guardian
ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
(g)Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R400.12417.
(j) supervisory approval before the change.
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
(b), (d), (f), (g), (j):
One of four closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of (b), (d), (f), (g) and (j) as required by the rule.
(e)

R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a

(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination

or a new physical examination shall be completed within 30
calendar days after placement.

(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each

(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child placing

R400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a written

Repeat Violation- Renewal 2019.

2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.

(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster care

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.1238(2)(d)(i) Foster home record:
The agency shall clearly specify the reason for the child’s removal from the
foster home.
SRM 200 Storage of CHRI
The Licensing Record Clearance record-CWL-1326 results shall be consistently
stored in the secured provider summary section of MISACWIS.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
R400.12604(1) Orientation and application.
The agency was advised documenting the applicant’s orientation or refresher
orientation in the family’s DHS-612, as well as consistently uploading the family’s
orientation sheet, may aid it in showing ongoing compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
this licensing period.
This incident related to an allegation that the relative/foster parent was arrested for
retail fraud while children who resided within the home were present. The special
evaluation found the foster home in violation of several foster home rules, inclusive
of: Unusual incident notification and Reporting foster home changes, related to a
household member’s involvement with law enforcement and the foster parent’s
11

arrest. Additionally, for Foster parent qualification, related to good moral character,
and being of responsible character and being suitable and able to meet the needs of
children and provide for their care, supervision and protection. The foster child was
removed from the home; and following conclusion of a joint investigation with
another government entity the agency recommended revocation of the foster home’s
license.
The agency acted appropriately in this instance and adhered to rules and
departmental timeframes.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
AND
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2019 Renewal Inspection
where it received a number of rule, ISEP and policy violations. The agency made
progress on the corrective action but was not completely successful with it. It
received repeat violations at indicated earlier in this report.
The second corrective action plan related to special evaluation 2020C0420014.
The agency was found in violation of ACT 116, 722.120(3)(a) related to a special
evaluation, and three departmental policy standards, one respectively related to
Family team meeting, Case worker contacts and Placement change. The agency
submitted an acceptable corrective action plan, on 3/24/2020. It is too early to
assess this corrective action plan’s compliance.
DCWL ANALYST SAFETY CONCERNS ADDRESSED
There was one safety alert.
Concern
The caregiver reported never receiving the medical authorization card.
Resolution:
The child was placed from the caregiver’s mother’s home into her home. That prior
relative caregiver provided this caregiver the medical authorization card. The
agency verified such and documented in MISACWIS.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
